metadata.title: Language Disorders  Preschool Children
anatomical location body part affected: Medical problems (e.g., genetic disorders, hearing loss, head injury) can result in injury to the anatomy of communication and lead to language disorders in children; however, language disorders often have no known physical cause(1)
description: Language disorders in preschool children can be developmental (present from birth) or acquired (resulting from injury or disease following typical language development). A child with a primary language disorder experiences difficulties mainly in the acquisition or use of language. A child with a secondary language disorder experiences language difficulties associated with a separate primary condition (e.g., hearing loss, head injury).(2) Language disorders in early childhood often result from a combination of biological and environmental factors. For example, the effects of prematurity could be compounded if that child is in a neglectful, unresponsive home environment.(3) For typically developing children, “preschool age” refers to the ages of 2 or 3 years to 5 years.(4) However, some older children with language and/or other delays function at this level and will display the same characteristics as younger, typically developing children. Language skills that correspond to those displayed by typically developing preschool-aged children have also been termed “developing language” skills. Children in the developing language stage have expressive vocabularies that contain more than 50 words and make sentences by combining words; however, their use of grammar is often incorrect due to their developmental stage and the fact that they are still learning basic sentence structure. If a child is chronologically between the ages of 2 or 3 years and 5 years but displays delayed language skills, he or she might still be in the prelinguistic or emerging language period.(4) For detailed information on the assessment and treatment of children in the emerging language period, please see Clinical Review…Language Disorders: Toddlers ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709106

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Signs and symptoms of a language disorder will vary greatly depending upon the cause of the disorder, the specific age of the child (chronological and developmental), and the child’s environment. The symptoms of language disorders can range from mild to severe and will vary among children as well as in the course of a given individual’s lifetime.(2,5) Symptoms of a language disorder in preschool children include deficits or delays in the following:

Receptive language: Poor understanding of age and experience-level vocabulary, poor understanding of different sentence structures (especially in contexts without situational cues), difficulty learning new vocabulary, difficulty understanding questions and following directions, difficulty understanding and recalling details from a story(4,6) –Authors of a study conducted in the United Kingdom with 22 preschool aged children (ten with mixed receptive-expressive language delay and 12 with expressive language delay) found that children with mixed receptive-expressive  language delay differed in their gesture use from those children who only had expressive language delay. Impairments in the ability to use gestures and comprehend symbolic/nonverbal information was associated with mixed receptive-expressive  language delay and was not present in children with only expressive language delay.(53) Researchers recommended further research with larger sample sizes, but considered that assessment and treatment of gestures and symbolic comprehension is important for children with receptive language delay

Expressive language: Difficulty retrieving and using vocabulary he or she understands (either in a test setting or during conversation), delayed use/production of a variety of sentence structures, low mean length of utterance (MLU), use of nonspecific vocabulary (e.g., “thing” vs. “soccer ball”), use of filler words (e.g., “ummm”), and difficulty learning words to songs and rhymes(4,6)

Speech, phonology, and speech-motor  development: Delayed syllable and word productions, limited production of speech sounds and speech sound combinations, difficulty feeding due to muscular weakness, paralysis, or dysarthric-like  features.(4) For detailed information on speech production and articulation disorders in children, seethe series of Clinical Reviews  on speech sound disorders

Pragmatics: Problems include ineffective use of language to communicate thoughts, wants, and needs, difficulty maintaining a conversational topic appropriately, difficulty taking turns in a conversation, difficulty maintaining joint attention, and problems maintaining engagement with a conversational partner(4)

Preliteracy: Difficulty learning the alphabet, difficulty learning letters and numbers, difficulty identifying sounds that correspond to letters(6) –For detailed information on preliteracy skills in children with language disorders, see Clinical Review…Language Disorders: Preschool Children (Preliteracy Skills) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709110 Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Prior to conducting an in-depth  speech-language  evaluation, or a transdisciplinary assessment, information should be gathered on the child’s developmental level. The child’s developmental level is usually determined by a psychologist or developmental specialist. This information can be compared with information on the child’s language skills to determine whether or not the child’s language skills are commensurated with his or her nonverbal abilities. Whether or not a discrepancy exists between language and nonverbal developmental skills will guide intervention recommendations and goals(4)

Published research shows that when parents are involved in the assessment and treatment planning stages of early intervention (EI) services, they are more likely to be invested in participating in those services.(10) Therefore, parents, caregivers, and other family members should be considered an important part of the assessment team and might provide information on the child’s strengths and weaknesses across communication contexts(4)

In order to obtain a clear view of a child’s developing language system, it is necessary to assess a range of areas (e.g., vocabulary, syntax, morphology, pragmatics, phonology) and to use a variety of assessment measures in order to examine each area in depth(11)

When assessing the language skills of young children, it is imperative to use developmentally appropriate contexts, content, and procedures. This might include observation of the child in his or her natural environment during typical or daily activities.(12) SLPs assessing the language skills of young children must also be aware of the variability among typically developing children as they learn language

When assessing young children at risk for communication disorders, it might be necessary to conduct multiple screenings, observations, or assessments over time as their skills and developmental expectations change rapidly.(4,11) It is incorrect to assume that the skills displayed by a young child during a single observation session completely represent the child’s abilities. Furthermore, long-term  predictions should not be made or communicated to parents based on a single sample of behaviors(3)

Although the use of standardized tests might be appropriate in some children (e.g., those from monolingual homes and those who are willing participants) and might identify global areas of delay, they do not identify patterns of difficulty nor do they identify specific areas to target during treatment. In order to identify patterns of errors that children exhibit in real-life  communication, standardized tests must be supplemented with criterion-referenced measures, such as language sampling, in order to assemble a profile of the child’s linguistic strengths and weaknesses.(4,11) For example, once a standardized language test has been administered and an expressive language delay/disorder identified, it is necessary to complete additional assessments, such as language sampling, in order to identify patterns of errors (e.g., difficulty using plural markers).(4) Due to time constraints, SLPs might need to use initial treatment sessions to gather additional, more detailed, assessment data(11)

Children often have co-occurring  articulation problems and language disorders. Therefore, it is recommended to assess both speech and language for preschool children who present with communication difficulties(4)

Although parents might report strong language comprehension skills, it is important for the SLP to differentiate between a child’s ability to comprehend oral language and a child’s ability to use nonverbal cues (e.g., gestures, eye gaze, context) to aid in following instructions and responding to a speaker appropriately(4)

risk factors: risk factors for language: Child factors–Very low birth weight(3,7)–Low 5-minute  Apgar score(7)–High birth order (third child or higher in a family)(7)–Being a multiple (e.g., twin, triplet)(8)–Chromosomal anomalies/genetic disorders(3)–Neurological disorders(3)–Congenital malformations(3,4)–Inborn errors in metabolism(3,4)–Sensory disorders(3,4)–Developmental disorders(3)–Severe toxic exposure(3,4)–Chronic medical illness(3)–Severe infectious disease(3)–Small for gestational age(3)–Experiences atypical or recurrent accidents(3)–Chronic otitis media(3)–Child experiences abuse or neglect(4)–Low socioeconomic status (SES)(55)

Parent/family factors–Late or no prenatal care(7)–Low level of education(3,7)–Entered parenthood at younger age(3)–Dependent on drugs or alcohol(3)–Parent/caregiver experiences a chronic or severe illness(3)–Family is in crisis(3)–Family displays chronically disruptive patterns of interaction(3)–Parent/caregiver is physically or socially isolated and/or has a lack of adequate social support(3)–Living conditions are unstable or dangerous(3)–Parent/caregiver is homeless(3)–Parent/caregiver has no or inadequate health insurance(3)–Severe prenatal complications(3)–Severe perinatal complications(3)

overall contraindications precautions: A young child’s family and/or caregivers must be included in the evaluation and intervention practice according to the U.S. Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA)(4)
Speech-language  pathologists (SLPs) should complete a review of a child’s medical and developmental history prior to conducting an assessment or intervention

When working with children and their families/caregivers, SLPs must display cultural sensitivity and be aware of the role of a family’s culture in their interaction patterns, ability to access services and information, and views of medical interventions and disabilities.(9) For detailed information on communication disorders in bilingual infants and toddlers, see Clinical Review…Language Disorders: Bilingual Infants and Toddlers ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709065. For detailed information on language disorders in school-aged  children, see Clinical Review…Language Disorders: Bilingual School-Aged  Children ; CINAHL Topic ID Number:T709066

The assessment and treatment of young children requires a team approach regardless of the setting (e.g., child’s home, preschool, rehabilitation center, hospital). Such a team will include the child’s family/caregivers, SLPs, occupational therapists (OTs), physical therapists (PTs), audiologists, early-education  specialists, preschool teachers and staff, nurses, physicians, and other team members as appropriate

Development of an individualized education program (IEP) in collaboration with the parents/caregivers and preschool teacher(s) might be appropriate for children with developmental disorders to address learning, language, cognitive, feeding, and/or motor problems
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Does the child have a primary disability (e.g., hearing loss, cerebral palsy, autism spectrum disorder [ASD], traumatic brain injury [TBI]) that might have caused a communication disorder?

course of treatment.medical management: Does the child receive medical management for any reason? If so, describe the medical management the child is receiving. Does the child have a history of prolonged hospitalization or time spent in the NICU?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what, if any, medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Unless a primary medical condition exists or is suspected, medical diagnostic tests are not common when diagnosing language disorders
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the child has had speech-language,  occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Does the child have an existing IFSP (individualized family service plan) or IEP?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factorsDoes the time of day, setting, communication partner, and/or health status influence the child’s communication skills?(3)Observations of the child’s interaction with the parent during play can yield valuable information. Does the child display infrequent or inconsistent responses to his or her environment? Are the child’s communication attempts inconsistent, of poor quality, or difficult for caregivers to interpret? Do parents/ caregivers show decreased responsiveness to their child? Do parents/caregivers demonstrate less affection and/or talk less frequently to their child? How adept are parents/caregivers at recognizing and responding to the child’s communication signals? Does a parent/caregiver suffer from a mood disorder (e.g., depression) or drug/alcohol dependency that could affect motivation to initiate or respond to communication?(3,13)Does the child have vision or hearing problems? Does the child have a motor impairment that affects his or her ability to communicate nonverbally and/or verbally?(13) -Children with language impairment have increased incidence of motor impairment, including impairment of the child’s ability to produce gestures to supplement communication attempts(14) If the child demonstrates delays in speech production, are these delays accompanied by delays in the child’s overall communication skills (i.e., delayed communicative function and frequency)? Does the child exhibit isolated difficulties in oral-motor  skills and speech production?(4)Patterns of child-caregiver  interaction vary significantly between cultural groups, and the SLP must be knowledgeable of typical interaction patterns in a specific child’s family.(15) In what ways does the family’s culture influence child-caregiver  interaction patterns? What language(s) is/are spoken by the child’s caregivers? Do language barriers affect the family’s access to information and/or services?(2)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: The symptoms of a language disorder in preschool-aged  children are highly variable and will be influenced by a child’s age, the severity of accompanying motor or cognitive impairments, a child’s medical status, and a child’s preschool, home, or hospital environment. Preschool-aged  children with language disorders are at increased risk for problems in the areas of receptive language, expressive language, preliteracy, and/or social language (pragmatics).(3,6,13) Additionally, preschool-aged children with language disorders might have accompanying oral-motor and/or speech production problems or dysphagia
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, with changes in the environment (e.g., during medical procedures, with different communication partners), and during different daily activities
history of present illness.other symptoms: Does the child display problems in the areas of voice, hearing, oral-motor  skills, and/or swallowing?(2) Document other symptoms the child may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., recurrent ear infections, difficulty hearing sounds in the environment, poor motor skill development, poor or unusual response to physical sensation, feeding/eating difficulties)Document symptoms within the child’s family (e.g., symptoms of depression, feelings of guilt or isolation, signs of abuse or neglect) and refer family to a social worker or psychologist if necessary(3) -In a study conducted in Australia, researchers found that 4-year-old  children with language impairment (when compared to typically developing peers) showed more negative dispositions and overall behavior difficulties(16)Prior to being evaluated for a language delay or disorder, a child should undergo audiological testing in order to rule out or identify hearing loss -Children with hearing impairment are at increased risk of both receptive and expressive language disorders(17) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the child previously been diagnosed with a language delay/disorder? Has the child previously been diagnosed with a developmental delay or medical condition that could cause a language disorder?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the child’s family/primary caregiver about other problems, including hearing loss, behavioral problems, motor problems, cognitive problems, and feeding/eating problems
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the child’s family/primary caregiver about other symptoms the child is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the child reside in the hospital or at home? Does the child attend daycare or preschool? How does the child communicate thoughts, wants, and needs in various settings and with various communication partners (e.g., gestures, eye gaze, vocalizations, words, word combinations, sentences)? What types of activities does the child enjoy? What does the family/primary caregiver consider to be the child’s overall strengths and weaknesses?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What functional communication limitations does the child experience in daily living? Does the child require the use of adaptive equipment for communication, mobility, and/or feeding?
social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -With whom does the child live? What language(s) are spoken in the home? In the home, with whom does the child primarily communicate? -Does the child attend daycare or preschool? What language(s) are spoken in the daycare or preschool? -Does the child experience an overall lack of language exposure at home? Decreased amount of linguistic input to children is often associated with a family’s poverty level and can negatively affect the child’s language skills(18) -Observe and describe interaction patterns displayed by the child and his or her family/caregivers or the child and his or her peers(3)

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting):
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document whether or not the child uses assistive and/or adaptive device for communication (e.g., hearing aids, communication board), mobility, or feeding. Children with language disorders might benefit from the use of augmentative and alternative communication (AAC). AAC ranges from manual signs and gestures to high-tech  devices that produce digitized and/or synthesized speech (speech-generating  devices). Research findings support the use of AAC for children with communication disorders to support communication development.(48) AAC has also been shown to be effective in terms of behavior change and generalization for individuals with severe expressive communication impairments.(49) In addition, research has indicated repeatedly that the use of AAC devices does not hinder natural speech development in very young children.(48) Furthermore, authors of a systematic review of studies of persons with significant speech impairments reported that many children had an increase in speech production following AAC intervention.(50) For detailed information on AAC, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language examinationA child’s speech production can be assessed through a combination of standardized testing, observation, parental report, and speech sample analysis(4) -In a study conducted in the United States, researchers found that children with specific language impairment had a significantly slower rate of articulation as compared to typically developing peers; overall speaking rate and pause time were not different, hence the difference appeared to be related to longer syllable duration in children with specific language impairment(19) -For detailed information on articulation and phonological disorders in children, see the series of Clinical Reviews  on speech sound disordersLanguage skills can be assessed using formal measures (e.g., standardized tests, parent-completed questionnaires, dynamic assessment language sampling) or informal observations. Several areas ofIf a child does poorly on a standardized test of vocabulary, analysis of standardized testing should be completed in order to identify classes or groups of words (e.g., spatial words, question words) that the child has difficulty understanding or expressing. Note whether or not the child displays signs of word-finding  difficulties (e.g., circumlocutions, use of overly general terms such as “thing,” or difficulty naming items comprehended on a receptive language test)(4) -Children with specific language impairment use fewer verbs in spontaneous speech and are less likely to use low-frequency  verbs as compared to typically developing peers(20)It is important to assess a child’s receptive and expressive syntax and morphology separately because 1) a child might produce a sentence structure expressively that he or she does not understand when nonverbal cues are removed, and 2) having information on both receptive and expressive skills will inform the course of treatment and goal selection(4)A child’s ability to understand language syntax might be affected by the context within which the language is used. For example, in contextualized settings, nonverbal support (e.g., gesture, eye gaze, objects in the environment) is present in order to aid the child’s comprehension of language which he or she might not understand in isolation. In decontextualized situations, such as while taking a standardized test, nonverbal support  is absent. Gathering information on a child’s ability to comprehend sentence structure in both contextualized and decontextualized situations will provide important information (e.g., is the child able to integrate verbal and nonverbal information?) and help determine the course of treatment (e.g., can the child benefit from a naturalistic therapeutic approach or does treatment need to address the comprehension of nonverbal cues?(4)If a child displays delayed expressive syntax/morphological skills on standardized test measures, criterion-referenced  measures can be used to further examine this area of language development. The collection and analysis of a spontaneous language sample can provide detailed information on a child’s expressive syntax and morphology. Several methods of language sample collection, transcription, and analysis exist.(4) When collecting and analyzing language samples, it is important that the SLP collect and score the data in a manner consistent with the reference database that will be used to analyze it. For example, SLPs must follow the database’s specific guidelines on how to identify utterances and morphemes and which types of utterances to include or exclude. Additionally, SLPs should be aware of the potential effects of setting, participants, activity, and type of material on the language sample collected(21)An MLU yields a measure of morphological complexity in a child’s language. To calculate MLU, a sample of at least 50 utterances is taken. The number of morphemes in this sample is divided by the number of utterances.(22,23) This calculation takes into account the child’s developing morphological skills and syntactic skills. Although MLU can be helpful to obtain a picture of the child’s current level of language development, as well as an outcome measure, it cannot identify language delay or disorder in isolation and must be combined with other measures in a diagnostic speech-language evaluation(23)Assess vocal function, including vocal quality, loudness, pitch, and endurance; if there are specific concerns regarding voice, refer to otolaryngologist for complete workup to rule out laryngeal pathologies prior to completing a full
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Review EI, school, and/or medical records for information on cognitive deficits and/or the presence of a learning disability. Document known or suspected cognitive or learning difficulties, such as reduced working memory capacity.(52) If cognitive, developmental, behavioral, or learning problems are suspected, refer the child to the appropriate professional (e.g., child psychologist)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment
Precautions will vary according to the individual patient and the severity of accompanying cognitive, motor, medical, and/ or feeding symptoms

Many early-childhood  programs stress parent education and parent involvement, and the U.S. Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) requires parent/caregiver involvement in the assessment and treatment process. However, SLPs should be aware of the cultural implications of these types of programs. Prior to beginning intervention services, the SLP must become aware of the family’s value of talk, the handling of social status in conversations, beliefs about when a child becomes able to communicate intentionally, and beliefs about how children learn language.(15) In addition to cultural variables, individual family variables may impact the level of involvement a family wishes to have in treatment provision (e.g., providing therapy following parent/family training, attending clinician-led  therapy sessions, completing homework sent by the child’s SLP)(4)

When planning treatment goals for preschool-aged  children, the SLP must be knowledgeable about typical developmental patterns and the sequence of language acquisition. However, when working with chronologically older children who are still in the developing language stage, SLPs might choose to focus on goals targeting functional language skills rather than those which are “next” to develop (e.g., using a complete sentence to ask for personal items even before the older child has mastered the prerequisite grammatical forms)(4)

During treatment sessions, the SLP must be aware of the impact of positioning on a young child’s ability to communicate. Children who are medically fragile or have accompanying motor disabilities may require special positioning or support in order to facilitate communication. SLPs should collaborate with PTs and OTs in order to address these concerns(3)

During treatment sessions, the SLP must be aware of sensory issues a young child has (e.g., hypersensitivity to touch, sensory integration difficulties) and their possible impact on the child’s ability to communicate. SLPs should collaborate with OTs in order to address these concerns
Development of an IFSP or IEP in collaboration with the parents and early-childhood  professionals may be necessary for children with language disorders and/or disorders/delays among multiple domains

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital/school and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary listed below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The diagnosis of a language delay or disorder in children is made by a fully certified and licensed SLP in collaboration with the child’s family and other medical and/or educational specialists
assessment plan of care.rule out: Typical variation in language performance and language differences attributable to second-language  acquisition (when appropriate)(2,18)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Appropriate referrals will depend upon the child and family’s individual needs. Referrals might be made to professionals in the following disciplines: audiology, occupational therapy, physical therapy, early-childhood  education, and social work
treatment summary: When working with a young child, intervention services should be family-centered  in that 1) communication develops in a natural context (e.g., during social interactions with a parent/caregiver), 2) communication and socioemotional development are reciprocal, and 3) childhood communication disorders directly affect the family system.(3,32) However, once a child reaches preschool, an IEP, focusing on the child, will be generated in place of an IFSP

Although IEPs focus on the educational needs of the individual child, parents/caregivers have legal rights allowing them to be involved in the assessment, treatment planning, and therapy stages of service delivery. Parents should be considered and treated as integral parts of the IEP team(4)
In order to generalize newly acquired language skills, it is important that treatment goals be targeted in a variety of contexts over a period of time(33)

When working with preschool-aged  children, SLPs can use clinician-directed  methods, child-centered  approaches, and/or hybrid approaches(4) –Clinician-directed  (CD) methods: CD methods include drill, drill play (e.g., target language form is practiced after every “turn” in a game), and the use of commercial software programs. CD methods, especially those involving computer  games, may be motivating to children and facilitate intense practice of language goals; however, it is important to employ strategies to generalize new language knowledge to the child’s daily life and to ensure that the child can use the new knowledge in socially appropriate ways(4) –Child-centered  (CC) approaches: CC approaches are generally recommended when the goal is to improve the child’s ability to communicate in general (rather than to address specific syntactical, morphological, or semantic goals). One example of a CC approach is indirect language stimulation (ILS).(4) In ILS: -Clinician and/or parent/guardian uses expansions, extensions, recasts, and open-ended  and verbal reflective questions when interacting with the child(4) -Expansions are adult responses to child utterances in which the adult repeats the child’s utterance in a way that corrects syntax, vocabulary, or articulation/phonology, but keeps the basic structure of the child’s utterance. For example, if a child says, “Him want milt” the adult corrects the statement by saying, “Look! He wants milk!”(51) -Extensions are adult responses to child utterances in which the adult responds to the child’s utterance with correct syntax, vocabulary, and articulation/phonology and extends the idea or topic of the child’s original utterance. For example, if a child says, “Him want milt” the adult responds by saying, “He wants milk. He must be thirsty!”(51) -Recasts are adult responses to child utterances in which the adult maintains the topic of the child’s utterance in a way that corrects syntax, vocabulary, or articulation/phonology, but changes the format of the original utterance in some way. Recasts can be basic or complex and sometimes additional information can be included in the adult’s recast. For example, if a child says, “Him want milt” the adult can recast the statement by saying, “Oh, look! Do you think he wants milk?”(51) -Authors of a systematic review (included 35 studies) and meta-analysis  (included 14 studies) on the effectiveness of recasts in language therapy with children found that the current evidence supports the use of recasts in language therapy for children with specific language impairment. Researchers did not find a strong evidence to support the use of recasts in language therapy for children with intellectual disability (ID); however, outcomes were generally positive. Because of the variety of methodology and outcomes measured, firm conclusions were difficult to make. Additionally, authors cautioned clinicians not to assume all parents who are taught about how to use recasts will be using them effectively or consistently. Parents of children with language impairment should be provided with frequent education about recasting in conversations with their child(51) -One-word  labels are provided for whatever the child is focusing on or referring to through the use of preverbal communication (e.g., providing a word label for an object to which the child is pointing)(4) –Hybrid approaches: Hybrid approaches are less structured than CD approaches, but provide more structure and clinician-direction  than do CC approaches.(4) Hybrid approaches include: -Milieu teaching: Intervention, which takes place incidentally in a conversational format within a natural setting, strives to teach new language forms in a functional context. However, the context is somewhat controlled so that the child 1) is required to initiate communication, 2) has a need to engage in social communication, and 3) receives natural rewards for his or her communication attempts.(4,34)MT is often described in the literature as an intervention for children with language disorders; however, the exact intervention protocols, including frequency and length of sessions, are not well-defined.(59) The effectiveness of MT for improving communication abilities in preschool children with language disorders is unknown. In a 2012 What Works Clearinghouse (WWC) Intervention Report published by the United States Department of Education, there were many studies that were found on MT in the literature; however, only one study from 1991 met the WWC standards to be included as part of the Intervention Report. According to this study, there was no apparent effect of MT on communication abilities.(59) Additional, well-designed studies are necessary to determine the effectiveness of MT on the communication abilities of preschool children with language disorders -Enhanced milieu teaching (EMT): EMT combines the features of milieu teaching (discussed above) with features of a responsive conversational style (in which models of appropriate language are provided). In a study conducted in the United States, the effects of EMT on six children with language disorders between the ages of 37 and 80 months were examined. Results indicated that EMT was effective in increasing the children’s use of targeted language structures during treatment sessions at home and in the classroom(34) -Focused stimulation: In focused stimulation, treatment is provided in the format of natural conversation. The SLP provides multiple models of the language target (e.g., use of auxiliary verbs) but does not require the child to produce the target. Although the child is not required to produce targeted structures, the environment is manipulated to encourage productions by the child. In addition to modeling the language target and manipulating the environment, “syntax  stories” can be incorporated into focused stimulation therapy. These are stories written collaboratively by the child and SLP and contain numerous examples of the target structure. Once written, the stories can be sent home as part of a home program. Parents are asked to read the stories to their child; however, the child is not asked to produce target structures(35) -Authors of a case study described the use of focused stimulation using both simplified syntactical input, as well as expanded input, with a 25-month-old  male child with a significant expressive language delay (receptive language skills were within normal limits)(36) -The child was enrolled in a 16-session  focused stimulation program during which developmentally appropriate words were targeted(36) -The first half of the sessions were completed with simplified input condition in which the clinician only used two to three word utterances with no grammatical relationship to target words (e.g., “Yes, look ball!”) and the second half of the sessions were completed with expanded input with a minimum of four words per utterance with grammatical information presented along with the target word (e.g., “The ball is bouncing.”)(36) -Ten words were targeted in each treatment condition; the child mastered 6/10 words in the simplified input condition and only 3/10 with the expanded input condition. For this specific child, focused stimulation to increase vocabulary was more effective when the clinician used simple syntactical input, focusing on the target word(36) -Script therapy: In script therapy, an emphasis is placed on using language in a familiar social context.(4) Since the child is familiar with the social context and knows the expectations of the routine event, both the child and the SLP/parent are able to focus their attention on the targeted language forms and/or content. During the course of script therapy, the expected progression of a routine may be intentionally interrupted by the adult in order to elicit additional language from the child.(4,33) In a study conducted in South Korea examining the effectiveness of script-based therapy, four preschool children with language disorders displayed improved use of semantic relation skills, the ability to generalize the use of these skills to other situations, and maintenance of these skills 3 weeks after script-based  therapy was discontinued(33)

During the preschool period, intervention can be carried out by a variety or combination of people: SLPs, paraprofessional (following the guidelines of the American Speech-Language-Hearing  Association), parents, carefully selected peers or siblings who are supported and trained by an SLP, and/or the child’s classroom teacher with support/training provided by an SLP(4,37)

Several models of service delivery exist and can be used when working with a preschool child with a language delay/ disorder: clinical model (child is seen either individually or in a small group in a specialized setting), language-based classrooms, collaborative model (the SLP provides intervention within the child’s mainstream classroom), and consultant model (the SLP trains the child’s teacher and/or parents in ways to modify classroom or daily activities to address the child’s language needs).(4) One collaborative model currently receiving attention by SLPs and early-childhood  educators is Response to Intervention (RTI)(38) –RTI -Principles of RTI(38) -Tiered instruction that is dependent on the individual needs of the child being served. Tiers vary according to level, frequency, and intensity of instruction -High-quality  instruction (involving knowledgeable professionals, varied instructional methods, ongoing assessment, matching experiences to child’s needs, and professional collaboration) -Research-based  core curriculum -Data collection to monitor student progress and instructional effectiveness coupled with attempts to understand a child’s current performance -Evidence-based  interventions -Instructional practices are selected and revised based upon set procedures (e.g., collaborating with the child’s family, consideration of the child’s needs and learning context) -Adherence to RTI principles is monitored -In order to work in early-childhood  settings that incorporate RTI, an SLP may need to:(39) -Gain additional training on the principles and implementation of RTI -Identify and provide preventive services to children at risk for language and learning difficulties -Spend more work time in a consultative role and in the mainstream classroom  -For detailed information on RTI, see Clinical Review…Response to Intervention (RTI) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709175

Shared-reading  intervention –Several studies have been conducted which point to the benefits of shared-reading  intervention for preschool-aged children with language delays/disorders.(40,41) Shared-reading  activities are book-centered  activities in which the child and adult work together to construct meaning from the book to which they are attending.(42) Shared-reading  is believed to be beneficial because: -Shared-reading  and exposure to literature enhances a child’s vocabulary development(43) -Shared-reading  activities offer contextual support (i.e., a book or familiar story) which allows the adult to use more complex language and supports the development of the child’s abstract language skills(40,43) -Oral language development and early literacy skills are interrelated and reciprocal(40) -Reading books is a natural activity for many mainstream American families and therefore allows intervention activities to be conducted in a naturalistic environment(42) -Providing intervention services during shared-book reading may strengthen the foundation upon which later literacy skills are built(42) -Once a book has been read, story retelling offers the opportunity to develop a child’s narrative language skills(43) –Despite the benefits of incorporating shared-reading  into a treatment program for language delays and disorders, prior to including these activities in a treatment plan, SLPs should consider an individual child’s/family’s perception of shared-reading  activities, the child’s motivation and desire to participate in book-related  activities, the effect (possibly negative) of changing a parent-child’s  interaction style, and ways to address goals in contexts other than shared-book reading to encourage the generalization of targeted skills(42)

Parent-based  video home training program –In a randomized controlled trial conducted in the Netherlands, researchers examined the results of a parent-based  video home training (PVHT) program for children who had been diagnosed with developmental language delay(44) -Twenty-two  subject groups; each subject group was made up of two parents and one child with developmental language delay; in each of the subject groups the mother was the main caretaker for the child and the families were all of middle-class social economic status (determined by a standardized interview prior to the study)(44) -The subject groups were randomly assigned to either the PVHT group or the control group; the members of the control group received direct child language intervention program (individual 45-minute  weekly speech and language therapy sessions for 12 weeks; parents did not participate in sessions and waited outside the room during sessions)(44) -The mothers in the PVHT group participated in a parent-oriented  video home training program for 13 weeks with 6 bi-weekly  home visits of 90 minutes each(44) -The goal of the PVHT program was to train parents how to use four strategies in their home to promote conversational coherence for their child with language delay(44) -Four strategies included: attachment (relation and affection between child and parent), referencing (using child-directed  behavior and child-adjusted  language to refer to observable ongoing activities and feelings), relevance (situational and linguistic context), and connectivity (connecting conversational acts to earlier utterances and conversations)(44) -Baseline and follow-up  measures were taken with all children before and after the completion of their assigned intervention. Outcomes included: -MLU(44) -PVHT: 2.1 (baseline) to 2.9 (follow-up) -Control: 2.3 (baseline) to 2.9 (follow-up) -Significant differences between the PVHT and control group with both grammaticality and conversational coherence at follow-up  with the PVHT group showing greater improvements(44) -In addition to having the same or better effects on the child’s language, the PVHT seemed to have continued long-lasting effects as demonstrated by continued improvement in all outcome measure scores between a post-treatment  assessment and follow-up three months later(44)  -Researchers concluded that parent training/education should always be incorporated into intervention programs for children with developmental language delay(44)

Research on the efficacy of language intervention –Authors of a meta-analysis  of 13 articles was conducted to examine the efficacy of treatment for children or adolescents with primary speech and language delay/disorder.(45) Results indicated that: -Children with phonological or expressive vocabulary difficulties benefited positively from intervention(45) -Mixed evidence exists concerning the effectiveness of therapy for children with expressive syntax difficulties(45) -The results for children with receptive phonology or language difficulties are inconclusive due to the small number of studies conducted in this area(45) -Interventions focusing on parent training and those that were clinician-administered  had no significant differences in outcome(45) -Interventions lasting longer than 8 weeks may be more effective than those of shorter duration(45) -Intervention for children with expressive language difficulties only may be more effective than therapy for children with combined receptive-expressive language difficulties (however, many studies exclude children with receptive language difficulties so the results are inconclusive)(45) –Authors of a systematic review of narrative-based  language interventions with children who have language impairment found moderate to large effect sizes for the nine studies included in the review; however, due to the limited number of participants included in each study, and the significant variation in methodology and materials, researchers cautioned clinicians about interpreting the results of this review. Narrative-based  intervention was classified as being in an emerging stage of evidence requiring further investigation with larger subject groups(46) .
